03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Aegon I Targaryen was a warrior of renown, the greatest Conqueror in the history of Westeros, yet many believe his most significant accomplishments came during times of peace. The Iron Throne was forged with fire and steel and terror, it is said, but once the throne had cooled, it became the seat of justice for all Westeros.

Bearing to his new realm a great weapon forged from fire and steel, Aegon used terror as his greatest tool in unifying what was once seven divided kingdoms. In almost every corner of the realm, stories were circulated about the Dragon King and eventually people began to look towards House Targaryen as their greatest hope - this marked one of the most significant turning points in history.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: The reconciliation of the Seven Kingdoms to Targaryen rule was the keystone of Aegon I’s policies as king. To this end, he made great efforts to include men (and even a few women) from every part of the realm in his court and councils. His former foes were encouraged to send their children (chiefly younger sons and daughters, as most great lords desired to keep their heirs close to home) to court, where the boys served as pages, cupbearers, and squires, the girls as handmaidens and companions to Aegon’s queens. In King’s Landing, they witnessed the king’s justice at first hand, and were urged to think of themselves as leal subjects of one great realm, not as westermen or stormlanders or northmen.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: The Targaryens also brokered many marriages between noble houses from the far ends of the realm, in hopes that such alliances would help tie the conquered lands together and make the seven kingdoms one. Aegon’s queens, Visenya and Rhaenys, took a special delight in arranging these matches. Through their efforts, young Ronnel Arryn, Lord of the Eyrie, took a daughter of Torrhen Stark of Winterfell to wed, whilst Loren Lannister’s eldest son, heir to Casterly Rock, married a Redwyne girl from the Arbor. When three girls, triplets, were born to the Evenstar of Tarth, Queen Rhaenys arranged betrothals for them with House Corbray, House Hightower, and House Harlaw. Queen Visenya brokered a double wedding between House Blackwood and House Bracken, rivals whose history of enmity went back centuries, matching a son of each house with a daughter of the other to seal a peace between them. And when a Rowan girl in Rhaenys’s service found herself with child by a scullion, the queen found a knight to marry her in White Harbor, and another in Lannisport who was willing to take on her bastard as a fosterling.

It was the king’s custom to bring one of his queens with him wherever he traveled, whilst the other remained at Dragonstone or King’s Landing, oft as not seated on the Iron Throne, ruling on whatever matters came before her.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: The other half he devoted to an endless royal progress, taking his court from one castle to another, guesting with each of his great lords in turn. Gulltown and the Eyrie, Harrenhal, Riverrun, Lannisport and Casterly Rock, Crakehall, Old Oak, Highgarden, Oldtown, the Arbor, Horn Hill, Ashford, Storm’s End, and Evenfall Hall had the honor of hosting His Grace many times, but Aegon could and would turn up almost anywhere, sometimes with as many as a thousand knights and lords and ladies in his train. He journeyed thrice to the Iron Islands (twice to Pyke and once to Great Wyk), spent a fortnight at Sisterton in 19 AC, and visited the North six times, holding court thrice in White Harbor, twice at Barrowton, and once at Winterfell on his very last royal progress in 33 AC.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.chatgpt_paragraph:
King Aegon spent nearly a year devoted to an endless royal progress, taking his court from one castle to another, guesting with each of his great lords in turn. He and Queen Visenya visited the Eyrie and Harrenhal and Riverrun, Lannisport and Casterly Rock, Crakehall and Old Oak, Highgarden and Oldtown. At the Arbor he even made a brief visit to Evenfall Hall for a festival held at Lord Monkeyface's estate. Everywhere Aegon went he was welcomed heartily as King of Westeros with banners flying from every castle across the Seven Kingdoms (save in Dorne).
 
During his travels Aegon also had time for other pursuits: exploring Tall Trees Town off the coast of Duskendale; hunting stags amidst Griffith Goode’s woods near White Harbor; or visiting some of the older sites where House Targaryen had their roots such as Dragonstone or old smokey Dragonmont atop its mountain home high above Gulltown. His visits often brimmed with drama as royals flocked to pay tribute; Addison Hill arrived making memories by hosting him at White Harbor while Sons Meraxes at Horn Hill gave him such comfort that it was said ten times more comfortable than any night he'd ever spent in King's Landing – despite being called home sweet home - though it is disputed how much love there was between them both! Historical sights like The Starry Sept were visited too – narrowly avoiding murder when a Dornish cutthroat seeking vengeance on Queen Rhaenys came too close for comfort! It certainly wasn't safe but many say it deepened ties between people scattered throughout every corner of the realm.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: “It is better to forestall rebellions than to put them down,” Aegon famously said, when asked the reason for his journeys. A glimpse of the king in all his power, mounted on Balerion the Black Dread and attended by hundreds of knights glittering in silk and steel, did much to instill loyalty in restless lords. The smallfolk needed to see their kings and queens from time to time as well, the king added, and know that they might have the chance to lay their grievances and concerns before him.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: And so they did. Much of every royal progress was given over to feasts and balls and hunts and hawking, as every lord attempted to outdo the others in splendor and hospitality, but Aegon also made a point of holding court wherever he might travel, whether from a dais in some great lord’s castle or a mossy stone in a farmer’s field. Six maesters traveled with him, to answer any questions he might have on local law, customs, and history, and to make note of such decrees and judgments as His Grace might hand down. A lord should know the land he rules, the Conqueror later told his son Aenys, and through his travels Aegon learned much and more about the Seven Kingdoms and its peoples.

As he continued his royal progress feasting, dancing, hunting, hawking, even travelling to the far ends of the realm for council with Grand Maesters and Lords alike, King Aegon confirmed one thing; ever house and person must remain loyal to him.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Aegon’s chief concern was peace. Before the Conquest, wars between the realms of Westeros were common. Hardly a year passed without someone fighting someone somewhere. Even in those kingdoms said to be at peace, neighboring lords oft settled their disputes at swordpoint. Aegon’s accession put an end to much of that. Petty lords and landed knights were now expected to take their disputes to their liege lords and abide by their judgments. Arguments between the great houses of the realm were adjudicated by the Crown. “The first law of the land shall be the King’s Peace,” King Aegon decreed, “and any lord who goes to war without my leave shall be considered a rebel and an enemy of the Iron Throne.”

With a decree from the chief septon of Westeros and common consensus among both petty lords and great kings alike, it was clear that he would go down as one of the greatest conquers in history. 03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: King Aegon also issued decrees regularizing customs, duties, and taxes throughout the realm, whereas previously every port and every petty lord had been free to exact however much they could from tenants, smallfolk, and merchants. 03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: King’s Landing grew up around Aegon and his court, on and about the three great hills that stood near the mouth of the Blackwater Rush. The highest of those hills had become known as Aegon’s High Hill, and soon enough the lesser hills were being called Visenya’s Hill and the Hill of Rhaenys, their former names forgotten. The crude motte-and- bailey fort that Aegon had thrown up so quickly was neither large enough nor grand enough to house the king and his court, and had begun to expand even before the Conquest was complete. A new keep was erected, all of logs and fifty feet high, with a cavernous longhall beneath it, and a kitchen, made of stone and roofed with slate in case of fire, across the bailey. Stables appeared, then a granary. A new watchtower was raised, twice as tall as the older one. Soon the Aegonfort was threatening to burst out of its walls, so a new palisade was raised, enclosing more of the hilltop, creating space enough for a barracks, an armory, a sept, and a drum tower.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.chatgpt_paragraph: Aegon, Visenya and Rhaenys led their army of dragons on the legendary Conquest to unite the Seven Kingdoms as one. Everywhere they went, new cities sprang up around them; wherever King Aegon and his sisters had passed through grew in prosperity and splendor. At King’s Landing had been merely a humble village before the Targaryens came, but when the three siblings flew off from Aegon's High Hill, Visenya's Hill and Hill of Rhaenys it was already becoming something grand. The crude motte-and-bailey fort that had thrown up at its centre nearing fifty feet high was soon replaced by seven great hills near the mouth of Blackwater Rush - all joined together with wide walls that seemed to burst out of its foundations. With every passing week a new building or street appeared; underground caves connected what had once been disparate entries into a single city larger than any other in Westeros. A cavernous longhall beneath it was roofed with slate in case of fire, making it clear even to those far beyond these gates that this was where power lay now - not at the Starry Sept or some other bastion deemed holy by men claiming to speak for godly authority.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Below the hills, wharves and storehouses were rising along the riverbanks, and merchants from Oldtown and the Free Cities were tying up beside the longships of the Velaryons and Celtigars, where only a few fishing boats had previously been seen. Much of the trade that had gone through Maidenpool and Duskendale was now coming to King’s Landing. A fish market sprung up along the riverside, a cloth market between the hills. A customs house appeared. A modest sept opened on the Blackwater, in the hull of an old cog, followed by a stouter one of daub-and-wattle on the shore. Then a second sept, twice as large and thrice as grand, was built atop Visenya’s Hill, with coin sent by the High Septon. Shops and homes sprouted like mushrooms after a rain. Amongst this new crowd were characters like Addison Hill, a hedge knight; Griffith Goode, Lord Edmyn Tully’s son; Evenstar of Tarth, an old Targaryen knight; Humfrey the Mummer, a fair Dornish cut-throat; Young Robin Darklyn, Robert Baratheon’s illegitimate son; and many others. 03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Unlike its rivals, however, King’s Landing had no walls. Accordingly, His Grace ordered the construction of a ring of walls about King’s Landing, as high and strong as those that protected Oldtown and Lannisport. The task of building them was conferred upon Grand Maester Gawen and Ser Osmund Strong, the Hand of the King. With assistance from Grand Maesters, lords across Westeros even at its far ends of the realm amongst others such as Evenstar of Tarth, High Septon of Oldtown or Griffint Goode (the short fair man) things seemed destined to turn around faster than anticipated.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: The institution of the king’s small council did not come into its full bloom until the reign of King Jaehaerys the Conciliator, but that is not to suggest that Aegon I ruled without the benefit of counsel. He is known to have consulted often with his various Grand Maesters, and his own household maesters as well. On matters relating to taxation, debts, and incomes, he sought the advice of his masters of coin. Though he kept one septon at King’s Landing and another at Dragonstone, the king more oft wrote to the High Septon of Oldtown on religious issues, and always made a point of visiting the Starry Sept during his yearly circuit. More than any of these, King Aegon relied upon the King’s Hand, and of course upon his sisters, the Queens Rhaenys and Visenya.
events: institution of the king’s small council
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.chatgpt_paragraph: At the ascension of King Jaehaerys the Conciliator to the Iron Throne, Aegon I Targaryen consulted with his two Queens Rhaenys and Visenya along with Grand Maesters, masters of coin and the High Septon of Oldtown for restructuring the kingdom. It was at that time when he instituted the king’s small council which had him visiting Castle Dragonstone every year in full bloom. Even Queen Visenya's Hill became a representation of this tradition with her statue placed there, allowing people from every corner of the realm to come seek her advise or pay their respect to their beloved queen. People in Westeros have been retelling these stories since then as they travel between Aerion's High Hill and Starry Sept where many could be seen celebrating during those days over exotic food atop a farmer's field.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Queen Rhaenys was a great patron to the bards and singers of the Seven Kingdoms, showering gold and gifts on those who pleased her. Though Queen Visenya thought her sister frivolous, there was a wisdom in this that went beyond a simple love of music. For the singers of the realm, in their eagerness to win the favor of the queen, composed many a song in praise of House Targaryen and King Aegon, and then went forth and sang those songs in every keep and castle and village green from the Dornish Marches to the Wall. Thus was the Conquest made glorious to the simple people, whilst Aegon the Dragon himself became a hero king.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.chatgpt_paragraph: Queen Rhaenys, Queen Visenya and King Aegon I set about the conquest of the Seven Kingdoms with vigour. Rhaenys rode her dragon Meraxes across the Dornish Marches showering fiery devastation as she flew; Visenya composed emotive songs to stir action in even the most passive of hearts, and King Aegon became a glorious figure for all in Westeros as he strode amongst his Sixteen Targaryens. With their armies full at bloom they marched on up to The Wall and beyond, conquering nearly every corner of their realm within one spectacular year. At each kingdom they visited they consulted with local Kings and sought advice from Lords and Ladies; wrote decrees; held High Septons in respect and honored Him at Starry Septs. They forged friendships with such families like House Hightower and Tully who welcomed them into their castles along the way or else like Lord Monkeyface met them in battle during the Dornish War. At Oldtown they even managed to be joyuous despite losses- songs were sung, wine tasted- it truly was becoming a frivolous entity before turning into something so grand that it would echo throughout history for centuries afterward!

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Queen Rhaenys also took a great interest in the smallfolk, and had a special love for women and children. Once, when she was holding court in the Aegonfort, a man was brought before her for beating his wife to death. The woman’s brothers wanted him punished, but the husband argued that he was within his lawful rights, since he had found his wife abed with another man. The right of a husband to chastise an erring wife was well established throughout the Seven Kingdoms (save in Dorne). The husband further pointed out that the rod he had used to beat his wife was no thicker than his thumb, and even produced the rod in evidence. When the queen asked him how many times he had struck his wife, however, the husband could not answer, but the dead woman’s brothers insisted there had been a hundred blows.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.chatgpt_paragraph: Queen Rhaenys stood tall in Aegonfort as she held court over the Seven Kingdoms (save in Dorne). She saw a man and woman argue their lawful rights and struck them both, chastising them for not giving her smallfolk all the respect they deserved. But her special love was reserved for her brothers, who were accompanying her to ensure that justice prevailed everywhere. As Queen Rhaenys spoke of this truth, she became composed yet frivolous with a showering of glorious words. Addison Hill and Meraxes stood by Queen Visenya's side while the Evenstar of Tarth sang King Aegon's praises from Starry Sept

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Queen Rhaenys consulted with her maesters and septons, then rendered her decision. An adulterous wife gave offense to the Seven, who had created women to be faithful and obedient to their husbands, and therefore must be chastised. As god has but seven faces, however, the punishment should consist of only six blows (for the seventh blow would be for the Stranger, and the Stranger is the face of death). Thus the first six blows the man had struck had been lawfu but the remaining ninety-four had been an offense against gods and men, and must be punished in kind. From that day forth, the “rule of six” became a part of the common law, along with the “rule of thumb.” (The husband was taken to the foot of the Hill of Rhaenys, where he was given ninety-four blows by the dead woman’s brothers, using rods of lawful size.)
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.chatgpt_paragraph: Queen Rhaenys had opened her court at the Hill of Rhaenys and consulted with maesters, septons, and other wise men from all over the Seven Kingdoms (save in Dorne). She rendered justice when necessary, but often chose to chastise instead of punish. For example, if she found a man or woman had been unfaithful to their partner, she would take away some of their lawful rights rather than striking them with a harsher punishment. In this manner, the queen showed her special love for the smallfolk, believing that they deserved justice just like everyone else.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Queen Visenya did not share her sister’s love of music and song. She was not without humor, however, and for many years kept her own fool, a hirsute hunchback called Lord Monkeyface whose antics amused her greatly. When he choked to death on a peach pit, the queen acquired an ape and dressed it in Lord Monkeyface’s clothing. “The new one is cleverer,” she was wont to say.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.chatgpt_paragraph: Queen Visenya Targaryen was a force to be reckoned with. Unlike her sister Queen Rhaenys who consulted with maesters and septons before taking any action, Visenya favoured brute strength as a means to an end. While ruling from the Hill of Rhaenys near King's Landing, she kept her own fool for amusement and even acquired an ape named Lord Monkeyface that she took great joy in dressing up in hirsute clothing. Her cleverness often left those around her amused and awestruck, but not all were enthralled - one famous Dornish cutthroat found his fate when he tried to take advantage of the Queen; choking to death on a peach pit after attempting to kill her whilst she sunbathed on Visenya's Hill. The love Visenya shared with Lord Monkeyface was so strong that many claimed it was no different than the faithful obedience given by Aegon I Targaryen’s husband-to-be Sixteen years earlier when he had sworn fealty at Aegonfort after the adulterous Robert Baratheon had been taken away by Humfreyhte Mummer. Despite this admiration however, few offered praise due to House Targaryens lawfulness being rendered unimportant across Westeros.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Yet there was darkness in Visenya Targaryen. To most of the world, she presented the grim face of a warrior, stern and unforgiving. Even her beauty had an edge to it, her admirers said. The oldest of the three heads of the dragon, Visenya was to outlive both of her siblings, and it was rumored that in her later years, when she could no longer wield a sword, she delved into the dark arts, mixing poisons and casting malign spells. Some even suggest that she might have been a kinslayer and a kingslayer, though no proof has ever been offered to support such calumnies.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.chatgpt_paragraph: Queen Visenya Targaryen had not been content to remain in King's Landing, instead, she often sought out adventure. Her dedication to her passions led her far and wide throughout the Seven Kingdoms (save in Dorne). She delved into mysteries of Old Oak and Dragonmont, mixing grim black magic with her skill at controlling dragons. Evenstar of Tarth said it was this combination of Viserys' fiery temper and dark sorceries that made Visenya one of the most unforgiving yet beautiful leaders Westeros had ever seen. She wielded power over Griffon Goode and House Hightower like a stern commander casting curses on anyone who opposed her rule; though some still claim that Lord Monkeyface became infatuated after she kept her own fool when his hirsute hunchback cousin proved cleverer than him.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: It would be a cruel irony if true, for in her youth no one did more to protect the king. Visenya twice wielded Dark Sister in Aegon’s defense when he was set upon by Dornish cutthroats. Suspicious and ferocious by turns, she trusted no one but her brother. During the Dornish War, she took to wearing a shirt of mail night and day, even under her court clothes, and urged the king to do the same. When Aegon refused, Visenya grew furious. “Even with Blackfyre in your hand, you are only one man,” she told him, “and I cannot always be with you.” When the king pointed out that he had guardsmen around him, Visenya drew Dark Sister and slashed him across the cheek so quickly the guards had no time to react. “Your guards are slow and lazy,” she said. “I could have killed you as easily as I cut you. You require better protection.” King Aegon, bleeding, had no choice but to agree.

When Aegon arrived on scene, he urged Visenya to take a step back as he fiercely confronted the man who had threatened them both; eventually convincing him to leave by imposing his stern beauty and unforgiving character.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Many kings had champions to defend them. Aegon was the Lord of the Seven Kingdoms; therefore, he should have seven champions, Queen Visenya decided. Thus did the Kingsguard come into being; a brotherhood of seven knights, the finest in the realm, cloaked and armored all in purest white, with no purpose but to defend the king, giving up their own lives for his if need be. Visenya modeled their vows on those of the Night’s Watch; like the black-cloaked crows of the Wall, the White Swords served for life, surrendering all their lands, titles, and worldly goods to live a life of chastity and obedience, with no reward but honor.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.chatgpt_paragraph: Aegon and Visenya took to the Seven Kingdoms in an effort to defend and take control as a unified force. They knew that if they were able to form the Kingsguard, not only would it send a powerful message of loyalty, but it would also keep the realm safe from outside aggressors. Aegon urged his sister Visenya to join him in surrendering their lives for the protection of the King- no matter the cost. As her heart raced with pride and fear, she refused even when he said he could face death alone; instead offering her own life as well so they may live together in purest white representing both nobility and finest knightly honor. Together they formed a group of 16 Targaryens who pledged themselves through chastity, obedience, courage and service until death- living out each day honoring these qualities with ferocity equally as cruel as their suspicious foes had ever seen them wield before in battle at Dornish War.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: So many knights came forward to offer themselves as candidates for the Kingsguard that King Aegon considered holding a great tourney to determine which of them was the most worthy. Visenya would not hear of it, however. To be a Kingsguard knight required more than just skill at arms, she pointed out. She would not risk placing men of uncertain loyalty about the king, regardless of how well they performed in a melee. She would choose the knights herself.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: The champions she selected were young and old, tall and short, dark and fair. They came from every corner of the realm. Some were younger sons, others the heirs of ancient houses who gave up their inheritances to serve the king. One was a hedge knight, another bastard born. 03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: These are the names of Aegon’s Seven, as written in the White Book of the Kingsguard: Ser Richard Roote; Ser Addison Hill, Bastard of Cornfield; Ser Gregor Goode; Ser Griffith Goode, his brother; Ser Humfrey the Mummer; Ser Robin Darklyn, called Darkrobin; and Ser Corlys Velaryon, Lord Commander. 03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.chatgpt_paragraph: Donning brave, honorable colors, a band of valiant knights called the “Serving with Valor” soon set off to every corner of the realm. 03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Sixteen Targaryens followed Aegon the Dragon to the Iron Throne, before the dynasty was at last toppled in Robert’s Rebellion. They numbered amongst them wise men and foolish, cruel men and kind, good men and evil.
